1

Welcome to ITProTV,

00:00:42.390 --> 00:00:43.920
Thank you for coming in today Steve.

14
00:00:43.920 --> 00:00:45.040
>> Hi how are you doing?

15
00:00:45.040 --> 00:00:46.210
>> Great, thank you.

16
00:00:46.210 --> 00:00:50.730
>> Well, what we're gonna do is look at a
whole series of slides here that have some

17
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:53.280
fundamental concepts associated with them.

18
00:00:53.280 --> 00:00:55.200
And you need to know these.

19
00:00:55.200 --> 00:00:59.220
When you're going for your first interview
for a security job, the expectation is

20
00:00:59.220 --> 00:01:02.900
that you would get some sort of
question that will relate to the triad.

21
00:01:02.900 --> 00:01:06.840
And the differences between the C and
the I and the A and

22
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:09.000
the nuances associated with each of those.

23
00:01:09.000 --> 00:01:13.820
So let me go through here and this slide
will help you get through this material.

24
00:01:13.820 --> 00:01:18.340
So the goal here is to understand
confidentiality, integrity,

25
00:01:18.340 --> 00:01:19.800
and availability.

26
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:24.200
Now confidentiality I guess the way
that I would think about it,

27
00:01:24.200 --> 00:01:28.200
if I wanted to simplify things,
is that there's data out there, and

28
00:01:28.200 --> 00:01:31.240

29
00:01:31.240 --> 00:01:35.650
need to understand its concepts,

00:01:39.470 --> 00:01:43.280

00:01:51.760 --> 00:01:53.900

a need-to-know basis, and

00:02:16.460 --> 00:02:19.840
that reminded me of another security
fundamental which I'm not sure if we'll

00:02:19.840 --> 00:02:23.770
cover but I'll just throw it out there and

44
00:02:23.770 --> 00:02:27.190
So you can also tie that into the C for

45
00:02:27.190 --> 00:02:30.038
And the principle of least
privilege basically states,

00:02:30.038 --> 00:02:33.990
it's a need-to-know basis not
everyone within an organization or

47
00:02:33.990 --> 00:02:37.250
entity has to have
the same blanketed access.

48
00:02:37.250 --> 00:02:40.410

an individual that they can go ahead and

00:02:40.410 --> 00:02:43.150
perform their job role, their function.

50
00:02:43.150 --> 00:02:43.970
>> Exactly.

51
00:02:43.970 --> 00:02:45.240
Let me give you an example, and

52
00:02:45.240 --> 00:02:49.150

when we talk about least privilege.

53
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:55.445
It's more a need to know basis, that's
a good definition of least privilege.

54
00:02:55.445 --> 00:02:57.935
You need to know what you
need to know to do your job.

55
00:02:57.935 --> 00:03:01.655
And to give you an idea, let's say
that we're talking about the army.

56
00:03:01.655 --> 00:03:04.665
And there's a combat platoon.

57
00:03:04.665 --> 00:03:09.185
And there's a sergeant that's
running this particular effort.

58
00:03:09.185 --> 00:03:12.465
And it's a secret mission.

59
00:03:12.465 --> 00:03:17.210
And we have a general on that same base
who's in-charge of the commissary.

60
00:03:17.210 --> 00:03:20.530
Now does that general have a need
to know about what the sergeant and

00:03:20.530 --> 00:03:21.840

62

>> So just to clarify that, so maybe

63
00:03:25.250 --> 00:03:29.360
As far as those ranks our general would be
underneath, a subordinate of our sergeant?

64
00:03:29.360 --> 00:03:30.210
>> No.

65
00:03:30.210 --> 00:03:31.165
>> No?
Okay, see?

66
00:03:31.165 --> 00:03:33.160
[LAUGH]
>> The sergeant,

67
00:03:33.160 --> 00:03:35.550
every time the general
comes by has to salute.

68
00:03:35.550 --> 00:03:36.160
>> Okay, the opposite.

69
00:03:36.160 --> 00:03:38.010
>> That's a requirement, right.

70
00:03:38.010 --> 00:03:38.600
Right.
So

71
00:03:38.600 --> 00:03:42.840
the sergeant is in-charge
of that particular mission.

72
00:03:42.840 --> 00:03:44.820
The general who's in-charge
of the commissary.

73
00:03:44.820 --> 00:03:46.210

384

00:18:32.830 --> 00:18:34.400
it may be physical, it may be.

00:18:36.450 --> 00:18:37.960
>> Subconscious, who knows?

387
00:18:37.960 --> 00:18:39.845
>> Maybe, I don't know.

388
00:18:39.845 --> 00:18:41.475
>> [LAUGH]
>> Maybe my phone.

389
00:18:41.475 --> 00:18:43.890
[LAUGH] That's probably a good thing.

390
00:18:43.890 --> 00:18:45.090
So that's basically it.

391
00:18:45.090 --> 00:18:47.000
Now in final thoughts,
when you go to the site and

392
00:18:47.000 --> 00:18:50.090
I've talked about it earlier,
put up items.

393
00:18:50.090 --> 00:18:55.340
I have one item up there and
it's showing you hashing and how it works.

394
00:18:55.340 --> 00:18:59.990
It's basically a site where you enter
a phrase and then you get its hash value.

395
00:18:59.990 --> 00:19:01.110

396
00:19:01.110 --> 00:19:04.460
It may be just be having a phrase and
putting a period on the end.

397

398
00:19:07.510 --> 00:19:10.810
there is no similarity
at all between the two.

399
00:19:10.810 --> 00:19:13.338
So that defines when we're talking about.

400
00:19:13.338 --> 00:19:17.100
>> Sending messages and
purifying the integrity of that message.

401
00:19:17.100 --> 00:19:19.390
>> Right, right, exactly.

402

00:19:29.845 --> 00:19:32.455

00:19:32.455 --> 00:19:36.895
So stay tuned, we do have more

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:02.640
Welcome to ITPro TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.640 --> 00:00:08.242
>> [INAUDIBLE]

3
00:00:08.242 --> 00:00:10.912
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.360 --> 00:00:15.310
>> Welcome Cyberpatriots to
your online training videos,

5
00:00:15.310 --> 00:00:17.480
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:21.070
In this particular episode we're gonna
be looking at, how a computer works.

7
00:00:21.070 --> 00:00:23.460
We'll look at some physical
hardware components.

8
00:00:23.460 --> 00:00:26.375
And with us today we have
Professor Steve Linthicum to go ahead and

9
00:00:26.375 --> 00:00:28.970
explain the different
components we'll be looking at.

10
00:00:28.970 --> 00:00:30.160
Thank you for joining us Steve.

11
00:00:30.160 --> 00:00:34.030
>> Right, so let's go through,
and I'm gonna bring up a slide.

12
00:00:34.030 --> 00:00:39.060
And this slide shows it's
characterized as Computer Anatomy 101.

13
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:42.721
And it shows a variety of devices,
and so we're gonna go through and

14
00:00:42.721 --> 00:00:44.940
talk about these devices.

15
00:00:44.940 --> 00:00:48.160
That big box in the center
that has CPU on it,

16
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:51.920
that is basically what we
commonly refer to as a computer.

17
00:00:51.920 --> 00:00:56.470
It contains the parts and
pieces that are internal to that box.

18
00:00:56.470 --> 00:00:57.890
And it includes the CPU,

19
00:00:57.890 --> 00:01:02.250
which we often characterize as
the brains of the computer.

20
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:05.090
It is where the processing is going on.

21
00:01:05.090 --> 00:01:10.160
It does mathematical calculations,
creates what we see on the screen.

22
00:01:10.160 --> 00:01:15.110
It is the central, I guess I'd
call it a device in the computer.

23
00:01:15.110 --> 00:01:16.078
>> Hence the name,
central processing unit.

24
00:01:16.078 --> 00:01:17.761
>> Yes, yes, exactly.

25
00:01:17.761 --> 00:01:19.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> And inside that box,

26
00:01:19.780 --> 00:01:23.150
you also have a couple other
components that are highlighted here.

27
00:01:23.150 --> 00:01:26.780
You have memory,
which is random-access memory.

28
00:01:26.780 --> 00:01:32.330
And your whole purpose, relative to that,
is it's temporary storage.

29
00:01:32.330 --> 00:01:36.520
It's what we call volatile storage,
meaning when the power goes out, whatever

30
00:01:36.520 --> 00:01:41.790
information was in that random-access
memory is gone, it's vaporized.

31
00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:44.330
And when you turn the power back on,

32
00:01:44.330 --> 00:01:50.430
then information is loaded in there that
the CPU needs to help process information.

33
00:01:50.430 --> 00:01:55.420
And periodically, programming,
basically, goes in and

34
00:01:55.420 --> 00:01:58.730
out and data goes in and out of the RAM.

35
00:01:58.730 --> 00:02:03.640
As the CPU needs it and
no longer needs it, it leaves RAM.

36
00:02:03.640 --> 00:02:06.230
And it's substituted with new information.

37
00:02:06.230 --> 00:02:10.060
If you really wanna improve a computer,
you have an older computer, let's say, and

38
00:02:10.060 --> 00:02:15.460
you want to improve its speed, this is
one place where you can spend some money.

39
00:02:15.460 --> 00:02:18.860
And improve your computer and
extend its life.

40
00:02:18.860 --> 00:02:23.410
The challenge with RAM is finding
out when you should upgrade.

41
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:26.400
And if you wait too long and
they quit making that RAM, guess what?

42
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:27.850
The price goes up.

43
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:31.516
So, as your computer ages and
they're still making that RAM,

44
00:02:31.516 --> 00:02:34.644
the price is going down,
down, down, down, down.

45
00:02:34.644 --> 00:02:35.996
>> Even on laptops, yeah.

46
00:02:35.996 --> 00:02:39.085
>> Yeah.
>> It's not always super expensive.

47
00:02:39.085 --> 00:02:41.788
And if you're not really familiar about,
there are so

48
00:02:41.788 --> 00:02:43.740
many different types of RAM out there.

49
00:02:43.740 --> 00:02:45.525
And we won't, I don't think we'll
get into all of that here, but.

50
00:02:45.525 --> 00:02:46.328
>> No, we won't do that.

51
00:02:46.328 --> 00:02:48.960
>> Yeah, you can use tools.

52
00:02:48.960 --> 00:02:51.670
On Crucial's website, they have little
tools that you can download, and

53
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:52.240
it'll tell you.

54
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:53.680
They make it really easy.

55
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:55.420
They want you to buy their product, right.

56
00:02:55.420 --> 00:02:56.850
You don't always have to buy it from them.

57
00:02:56.850 --> 00:02:58.492
You can go to other vendors and buy it.

58
00:02:58.492 --> 00:03:03.270
But it's a really,
I would say relatively inexpensive.

59
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:05.790
Now if you're talking high end,
that's a different story.

60
00:03:05.790 --> 00:03:11.230
But it's a relatively inexpensive way to
see an immediate return on investment.

61
00:03:11.230 --> 00:03:14.230
You'll notice those speeds definitely
kicking into gear there Steve.

62
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:16.427
>> Well, and the reality is,
that your extending the life.

63
00:03:16.427 --> 00:03:18.584
Because eventually you're
gonna replace the computer.

64
00:03:18.584 --> 00:03:22.784
Computers it's not that they,
well they could break I guess, but

65
00:03:22.784 --> 00:03:25.740
chances are they probably won't break.

66
00:03:25.740 --> 00:03:28.270
It would just get to a point
where you can't effectively

67
00:03:28.270 --> 00:03:30.560
run the software of today on it.

68
00:03:30.560 --> 00:03:36.300
>> Right, because the software's requiring
more processing power, more RAM.

69
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:40.774
Because we want more graphics, we want
better color rendering, 3D effects,

70
00:03:40.774 --> 00:03:44.405
things like that, and our systems,
they kind of get outdated.

71
00:03:44.405 --> 00:03:45.175
>> Right.
>> That's the truth.

72
00:03:45.175 --> 00:03:45.749
>> Right.

73
00:03:45.749 --> 00:03:46.850
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, exactly.

74
00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:51.960
>> The next item over here that they
talk about as hardware is storage.

75
00:03:51.960 --> 00:03:54.330
And typically inside a computer,

76
00:03:54.330 --> 00:03:58.670
inside that box where the CPU is located,
you'll have hard drives.

77
00:03:58.670 --> 00:04:01.240
We have two basic types of hard drives.

78
00:04:01.240 --> 00:04:03.284
We have ones that are what
we call spinning,

79
00:04:03.284 --> 00:04:05.566
meaning they have mechanical
components in it.

80
00:04:05.566 --> 00:04:09.079
And actually there's platters that are
spinning around, and around, and around.

81
00:04:09.079 --> 00:04:12.840
And eventually hard drives
like this will fail.

82
00:04:12.840 --> 00:04:16.228
They'll fail because they're
a mechanical device.

83
00:04:16.228 --> 00:04:20.436
And so we have in a more recent computers,

84
00:04:20.436 --> 00:04:27.420
we're using solid memory I guess is
the way I would characterize it.

85
00:04:27.420 --> 00:04:28.840
And-
>> It actually looks like

86
00:04:28.840 --> 00:04:32.475
memory sticks if you take the casing
off of these solid state drives.

87
00:04:32.475 --> 00:04:34.020
>> Right.
>> Yeah they're using that solid

88
00:04:34.020 --> 00:04:35.500
state memory.

89
00:04:35.500 --> 00:04:38.960
And the good news is,
you don't have parts that wear out,

90
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:43.240
although the constant movement
of information on and

91
00:04:43.240 --> 00:04:48.360
off will eventually cause these solid
state drives to fail, potentially.

92
00:04:48.360 --> 00:04:52.050
I'm telling you this because I think we
had a discussion on an earlier video about

93
00:04:52.050 --> 00:04:53.150
backing up.

94
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:59.160
So expect stuff that's on, and I say
stuff, information that's on these drives.

95
00:04:59.160 --> 00:05:01.850
Expect that they will fail, and

96
00:05:01.850 --> 00:05:05.360
with their failure you could
potentially lose this information.

97
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:08.200
So again, that's a reason for backing up.

98
00:05:08.200 --> 00:05:13.370
Now inside of this box today, or inside
of this laptop that's in front of me.

99
00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:16.410
There isn't an awful lot
that you can do today.

100
00:05:16.410 --> 00:05:22.810
Back, in the 80s it was,
you'd always build your own computers.

101
00:05:22.810 --> 00:05:24.580
And you could do all kinds of-
>> Well not even that long ago.

102
00:05:24.580 --> 00:05:25.961
>> Okay.

103
00:05:25.961 --> 00:05:26.780
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm

104
00:05:26.780 --> 00:05:29.760
trying to think of when I
built my last computer.

105
00:05:29.760 --> 00:05:36.680
And truthfully it's been quite some time
ago because it's just cheaper to buy one.

106
00:05:36.680 --> 00:05:40.830
Number one probably, there isn't
that return on investment saving

107
00:05:40.830 --> 00:05:43.710
yourself money by building your own.

108
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:47.340
Although if you're gamer, probably make
some sense maybe to build your own

109
00:05:47.340 --> 00:05:51.050
computer because you can put the sort of
graphic card in there that you want and

110
00:05:51.050 --> 00:05:52.450
other components.

111
00:05:52.450 --> 00:05:57.210
>> For me it was appealing because I
might not have had the full money.

112
00:05:57.210 --> 00:06:00.140
And if I wanted to upgrade later down
the road, I still had that option.

113
00:06:00.140 --> 00:06:02.714
I didn't have all the money up front and
then I can go ahead and

114
00:06:02.714 --> 00:06:04.645
switch parts out later on down the road,
so.

115
00:06:04.645 --> 00:06:07.493
>> Yeah, I don't know.

116
00:06:07.493 --> 00:06:11.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> It isn't as much fun today in my mind,

117
00:06:11.490 --> 00:06:14.400
because there isn't as
much that you have to do.

118
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:19.120
Way back in the early days of computing
you had to deal with IRQs and

119
00:06:19.120 --> 00:06:22.910
IO addressing in a variety of settings,
where you have to go through and

120
00:06:22.910 --> 00:06:24.540
move these little dip switches.

121
00:06:24.540 --> 00:06:26.850
And it was a challenge,
it was a challenge putting them together.

122
00:06:26.850 --> 00:06:28.360
But not so much today.

123
00:06:28.360 --> 00:06:31.790
About the only thing that I do with
computers is put in additional RAM, for

124
00:06:31.790 --> 00:06:34.520
example, or a new hard drive.

125
00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:36.090

>> Okay, so looking at this first

there are only three that

This is a representation of a variety
of devices that exist out there.

28
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:32.530
And as you can see,
the first line item is servers.

29
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:34.960
And I wanna explain
something about servers.

30
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:40.170
When I use that term,
it's somewhat confusing.

31
00:01:40.170 --> 00:01:44.720
It's always been somewhat confusing for
students in that if you go to your Windows

32
00:01:44.720 --> 00:01:49.300
7 machine, and you decide

33
00:01:49.300 --> 00:01:54.220
that people are gonna print through

And so it is a server.

35
00:01:56.110 --> 00:01:57.160
And if you-

36

folders out, and other people

37
00:02:01.220 --> 00:02:05.350

38

It is a server.

39
00:02:06.570 --> 00:02:08.650
It is providing a service.

So the fact that we talk about servers,

00:02:19.020 --> 00:02:21.270
>> Even though it is running

it's providing a service to others on your

45
00:02:26.030 --> 00:02:30.410
Don't get too boxed in, and

46

you have to really kind of keep your mind
open when you're discussing devices.

47
00:02:34.860 --> 00:02:39.381

that it's not always cut and dry,

48
00:02:39.381 --> 00:02:43.684
black and white, there are some kind
of grey areas that we just need to,

00:02:43.684 --> 00:02:46.434
it's kind of really exciting though Steve.

50
00:02:46.434 --> 00:02:50.885
Because you think of something in your
head, and this is not just with networking

00:02:50.885 --> 00:02:55.350
but in any kind of computing and

52
00:02:55.350 --> 00:02:57.350
Well, the answer is yes.

53
00:02:57.350 --> 00:03:00.930
Even though something doesn't exist
at this present moment in time,

54
00:03:00.930 --> 00:03:02.350
it's probably doable.

55
00:03:02.350 --> 00:03:06.390
And so that's kind of the really,
really cool thing about working in IT.

56
00:03:06.390 --> 00:03:07.190
>> Right.

57
00:03:07.190 --> 00:03:11.470
And so if we get back to the slide and
go through a few of these other devices.

58
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:12.040
Switches.

59
00:03:12.040 --> 00:03:15.917
Now when I started in networking,
well nobody could afford switches,

60
00:03:15.917 --> 00:03:17.220
I guess is the point.

61
00:03:17.220 --> 00:03:18.370
We probably had them.

62
00:03:18.370 --> 00:03:19.830
We called them bridges.

63
00:03:19.830 --> 00:03:20.750
>> Or hubs.

64
00:03:20.750 --> 00:03:23.350
>> Well hubs was the standard back then.

65
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:28.864
And a hub is nothing more than
some signals come in one port.

66
00:03:28.864 --> 00:03:33.420
And when we talk about ports, as you can
see on the front of that switch up there,

67
00:03:33.420 --> 00:03:35.610
those are where you would plug cables in.

68
00:03:35.610 --> 00:03:39.250
So a signal would come in
one of those ports and

69
00:03:39.250 --> 00:03:41.870
then it would be sent out all the ports.

70
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:44.440
It wasn't a smart device.

71
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:46.560
>> Yeah, because what you're
doing is generating traffic,

72
00:03:46.560 --> 00:03:49.230
and you've been here in Gainesville.

73
00:03:49.230 --> 00:03:51.760
Traffic's no fun,
no one likes traffic, right.

74
00:03:51.760 --> 00:03:52.870
[LAUGH]
>> Especially when it's

75
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:54.105
uncontrolled traffic.

76
00:03:54.105 --> 00:03:56.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that's the function of a switch.

77
00:03:56.810 --> 00:04:00.090
A switch is a computer, basically,

78
00:04:00.090 --> 00:04:03.580
everything on this screen's
a computer except for the people.

79
00:04:03.580 --> 00:04:11.030
But a switch is a computer,
a switch has memory, it has a processor.

80
00:04:11.030 --> 00:04:16.240
What happens is a signal comes in, and the
switch eventually learns what computers or

81
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:18.430
what devices are connected up to the port.

82
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:22.290
And so a signal comes in
to go to another port, and

83
00:04:22.290 --> 00:04:26.190
the switch knows based upon addressing
what wire is sending that out.

84
00:04:26.190 --> 00:04:30.338
So rather than sending it out all of
the ports like a hub would do it,

85
00:04:30.338 --> 00:04:35.510
it sends it out a single one to
the recipient, to the intended recipient.

86
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:37.100
So that's kind of sort of the way, yes.

87
00:04:37.100 --> 00:04:39.000
>> Reducing the traffic,
more intelligent way,

88
00:04:39.000 --> 00:04:43.650
that's why we see these smarter devices
being used in our modern networks.

89
00:04:43.650 --> 00:04:44.210
>> Okay.

90
00:04:44.210 --> 00:04:49.220
And a router is similar to a switch,
but what it's designed to do

91
00:04:49.220 --> 00:04:54.520
is to send traffic out of
the network to another network.

92
00:04:54.520 --> 00:04:56.780
That's probably the best
way to look at it.

93
00:04:56.780 --> 00:05:00.500
>> Aside from, yeah going into the OSI
model with the layers, and the addressing.

94
00:05:00.500 --> 00:05:02.363
>> And
we're not gonna do that to you guys today.

95
00:05:02.363 --> 00:05:04.237
>> Yeah, we're not gonna do that.

96
00:05:04.237 --> 00:05:06.244
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're not gonna do that.

97
00:05:06.244 --> 00:05:08.150
>> So I like your description there, yeah.

98
00:05:08.150 --> 00:05:11.800
>> The router that they've
identified here, in the upper, well,

99
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:13.260
next to the world, up there.

100
00:05:13.260 --> 00:05:15.710
Notice that it has some
things sticking up.

101
00:05:15.710 --> 00:05:19.212
And those are antennas, and so
this is probably that pretty standard,

102
00:05:19.212 --> 00:05:22.144
sort of,
wireless router that you have at home.

103
00:05:22.144 --> 00:05:23.470
>> An all in one.

104
00:05:23.470 --> 00:05:29.230
>> Yeah, yeah and so
it's a switch because the internal network

105
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:34.040
is being switched, and
in effect it's a router because it's

106
00:05:34.040 --> 00:05:39.160
routing traffic out to the Internet and
back from the Internet to your machines.

107
00:05:39.160 --> 00:05:40.430
The interesting thing about and

108
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:41.160
we mentioned earlier-
>> So

109
00:05:41.160 --> 00:05:42.700
these devices are working as a team here?

110
00:05:42.700 --> 00:05:43.250
>> Right.

111
00:05:43.250 --> 00:05:46.400
The interesting thing is those
antennas that are sticking up,

112
00:05:46.400 --> 00:05:49.890
they're using the airwaves, okay.

113
00:05:49.890 --> 00:05:53.180
And they're using typically
a single frequency,

114
00:05:53.180 --> 00:05:57.740
meaning they're behaving much like
a hub in that all the traffic,

115
00:05:57.740 --> 00:06:01.820
the wireless traffic,
is sharing that same media.

116
00:06:01.820 --> 00:06:06.790
And so they have to take turns
communicating, the computers,

117
00:06:06.790 --> 00:06:11.080
my laptop when it's hooked up to a
wireless network, it has to wait its turn

118
00:06:11.080 --> 00:06:16.920
to communicate with that,
basically an access point.

119
00:06:16.920 --> 00:06:22.440
That's the aspect with the antennas, and
so it behaves much like a hub environment.

120
00:06:22.440 --> 00:06:24.690
That's why wireless is generally slower.

121
00:06:24.690 --> 00:06:26.660
>> Yeah, and Steve,
wireless is so popular.

122
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:29.720
It's really flexible,
I can walk around with my devices.

123
00:06:29.720 --> 00:06:32.130
From a security standpoint and

124
00:06:32.130 --> 00:06:34.570
maybe there are other benefits that
you might want to mention as well.

125
00:06:34.570 --> 00:06:37.310
Why do we see companies
still using old cable?

126
00:06:37.310 --> 00:06:38.910
Who uses that stuff anymore?

127
00:06:38.910 --> 00:06:40.770
>> Well,
it's because of the speed primarily.

128
00:06:40.770 --> 00:06:41.760
>> Speed, number one.

129
00:06:41.760 --> 00:06:44.330
>> Right, and security, number two.

130
00:06:44.330 --> 00:06:46.390
>> Yeah.
>> Because, guess what?

131
00:06:46.390 --> 00:06:52.467
Yeah, if I can access the airways,
so can some hacker out there, yeah.

132
00:06:52.467 --> 00:06:53.760
>> Very easier than a wired network.

133
00:06:53.760 --> 00:06:55.120
>> Yes, much easier than wired.

134
00:06:55.120 --> 00:06:59.740
You have to tap in in some fashion,
and it's easy to tap into the airways.

135
00:06:59.740 --> 00:07:00.690
>> Yeah.
>> Because

136
00:07:00.690 --> 00:07:05.610
all you gotta do is to have a wireless
card on your machine and you're attached.

137
00:07:05.610 --> 00:07:08.910
The final device that they
mention here is a firewall, and

138
00:07:08.910 --> 00:07:13.900
often times this is built into this device
that has the antennas on it at your home.

139
00:07:13.900 --> 00:07:18.300
This is your firewall protecting your

140
00:07:19.510 --> 00:07:23.280
network from bad things coming in or-
>> It's kind of your

141
00:07:23.280 --> 00:07:24.560
first line of defense there.

142
00:07:24.560 --> 00:07:25.715
>> Right, exactly.

143
00:07:25.715 --> 00:07:28.940
And this is a firewall device.

144
00:07:28.940 --> 00:07:32.000
Many of our operating
systems on a host base.

145
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:36.270
We're talking about, again,
our Windows 7 machine for example.

146
00:07:36.270 --> 00:07:38.280
They have their own built-in firewall.

147
00:07:38.280 --> 00:07:40.275
>> The Windows Firewall in the software.

148
00:07:40.275 --> 00:07:42.840
>> Right.
>> And we don't have to pick and

149
00:07:42.840 --> 00:07:43.410
choose here.

150
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:45.990
It's actually recommended to use both.

151
00:07:45.990 --> 00:07:49.460
A network firewall in addition
to your host-based firewall.

152
00:07:49.460 --> 00:07:51.040
They're not gonna be conflicting there,

153
00:07:51.040 --> 00:07:53.532
they're just gonna be
restricting that access.

154
00:07:53.532 --> 00:07:56.370
>> Right, and one of the points
here with this diagram is,

155
00:07:56.370 --> 00:07:59.070
notice the machine that
is on the Internet.

156
00:07:59.070 --> 00:08:00.750
It is the router.

157
00:08:00.750 --> 00:08:04.930
Okay, so
it has physical access to the internet.

158
00:08:04.930 --> 00:08:08.230
All the other devices have
kind of a secondary access

159
00:08:08.230 --> 00:08:09.898
that are inside our network.

160
00:08:09.898 --> 00:08:15.160
And so it's a wise thing not to, for
example, connect to your laptop but

161
00:08:15.160 --> 00:08:18.990
directly to your modem,
you call it a modem, its not a modem.

162
00:08:18.990 --> 00:08:20.370
But your DSL modem, or

163
00:08:20.370 --> 00:08:24.510
your cable modem, because it
becomes the device on the Internet.

164
00:08:24.510 --> 00:08:29.785
And you don't want that, you want it
insulated, you want it in a private

165
00:08:29.785 --> 00:08:34.822
network, not with a public IP
address that's part of the Internet.

166
00:08:34.822 --> 00:08:38.155
>> And because this router's sitting
here on the perimeter of our network,

167
00:08:38.155 --> 00:08:40.795
we could also hear the term
default gateway being used.

168
00:08:40.795 --> 00:08:42.455
So don't get confused.

169
00:08:42.455 --> 00:08:43.605
Different vendors.

170
00:08:43.605 --> 00:08:47.150
You'll learn about that as you progress,
but just to kind of throw some extra terms

171
00:08:47.150 --> 00:08:49.566
out there for
you like you don't have enough already.

172
00:08:49.566 --> 00:08:52.010
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, so let's go on to the next slide.

173
00:08:52.010 --> 00:08:52.580
>> Sure.

174
00:08:52.580 --> 00:08:55.898
>> And
some of this we've basically talked about.

175
00:08:55.898 --> 00:09:00.780
Wireless access points, again on our
diagram that was actually that thing with

176
00:09:00.780 --> 00:09:06.160
the antennas, it's a combination
access point router switch.

177
00:09:07.230 --> 00:09:12.660
Access, users given access to more
data and devices on the network than

178
00:09:13.730 --> 00:09:18.030
necessary can inadvertently, or
purposefully, cause security issues.

179
00:09:18.030 --> 00:09:20.140
We need to harden our network.

180
00:09:20.140 --> 00:09:22.640
We need to make sure that, for

181
00:09:22.640 --> 00:09:26.910
example at my college we have
a Student Health Services department.

182
00:09:26.910 --> 00:09:30.390
And there are legal reasons
why that department's

183
00:09:30.390 --> 00:09:33.510
equipment shouldn't be on
the general network for

184
00:09:33.510 --> 00:09:37.320
the college because of privacy
concerns relating to health records.

185
00:09:37.320 --> 00:09:41.350
So we need to design our
networks with security in mind.

186
00:09:41.350 --> 00:09:44.730
>> And if you guys hear this term NAC,
network access control,

187
00:09:44.730 --> 00:09:46.660
that's exactly what Steve's
mentioning in here.

188
00:09:46.660 --> 00:09:50.040
You're just controlling who
has access to your network.

189
00:09:50.040 --> 00:09:50.670
>> Right.

190
00:09:50.670 --> 00:09:52.140
Email, guess what?

191
00:09:52.140 --> 00:09:56.330
We all know about email, we all know
about how we can be tricked into

192
00:09:56.330 --> 00:10:00.560
giving information through phishing,
tax, we've already talked about that.

193
00:10:00.560 --> 00:10:04.030
Firewall, it may be improperly configured.

194
00:10:04.030 --> 00:10:08.860
Oftentimes it is, and
the reason it is particularly in a home

195
00:10:08.860 --> 00:10:14.240
environment is because security
can often eliminate our ability

196
00:10:14.240 --> 00:10:18.940
to do things in an open environment,
open for example wireless environment.

197
00:10:18.940 --> 00:10:21.409
>> The Xbox isn't working with
those secure settings, so

198
00:10:21.409 --> 00:10:25.390
you know what let's just take those secure
settings off so I can play my games.

199
00:10:25.390 --> 00:10:28.230
>> And it's much easier,
rather then selecting secure settings,

200
00:10:28.230 --> 00:10:32.700
to take them all off And that's not a lie.

201
00:10:32.700 --> 00:10:36.000
>> A lot of router companies have
realized that people do that.

202
00:10:36.000 --> 00:10:39.820
And that's where you'll see UPNP for
Universal Plug and Play.

203
00:10:39.820 --> 00:10:44.060
There's a lot of routers at the home
versions have that setting because

204
00:10:44.060 --> 00:10:47.040
people were doing that so
often, but not all of them.

205
00:10:47.040 --> 00:10:50.247
>> And of course there are security
problems with Universal Plug and Play.

206
00:10:50.247 --> 00:10:50.762
>> Yep.

207
00:10:50.762 --> 00:10:52.360
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah so.

208
00:10:52.360 --> 00:10:54.560
>> That's another whole episode.

209
00:10:54.560 --> 00:10:56.600
Like you said,
you've got your college courses.

210
00:10:56.600 --> 00:11:00.982
There are people, their entire careers
are devoted for network engineers, and

211
00:11:00.982 --> 00:11:03.120
that's what they focus on.

212
00:11:03.120 --> 00:11:03.860
>> Exactly.
And

213
00:11:03.860 --> 00:11:06.790
then the final bulleted item
here is communications.

214
00:11:06.790 --> 00:11:11.770
Network traffic contains confidential
information, and I come back to this and

215
00:11:11.770 --> 00:11:15.460
I'll repeat it, and I'll repeat it, and
I'll repeat it, what we need to do for

216
00:11:15.460 --> 00:11:20.420
security is have encryption in storage and
encryption in transit.

217
00:11:20.420 --> 00:11:23.970
And they talk here about
Secure Socket Layer technology.

218
00:11:23.970 --> 00:11:27.460
This is what happens when you go on
the Internet and you get that lock.

219
00:11:27.460 --> 00:11:33.070
That indicates that this sort of

1

Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2

3

4

5

6
00:00:15.268 --> 00:00:17.310
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.310 --> 00:00:21.078
And just as promised, in this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and

8
00:00:21.078 --> 00:00:23.880
cover some Windows version history.

9
00:00:23.880 --> 00:00:27.440
Here with us, we have our guru,
our expert, our historian,

10
00:00:27.440 --> 00:00:29.156
Professor Steve Linthicum.

11
00:00:29.156 --> 00:00:31.032
Thank you for coming today, Steve.

12
00:00:31.032 --> 00:00:31.817
>> Right.

13
00:00:31.817 --> 00:00:33.888
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

14
00:00:33.888 --> 00:00:36.521
>> Yeah, I'm gonna be the historian, and

15
00:00:36.521 --> 00:00:40.704
part of it stems from the fact that
I first became acquainted with

16
00:00:40.704 --> 00:00:43.270
personal computers back in 1981.

17
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:49.534
Which happens to be at the time that the
IBM PC was first available for public use.

18
00:00:49.534 --> 00:00:53.776
And I was actually involved
in it before then.

19
00:00:53.776 --> 00:00:59.499
I go back to my college days and we used
to program using IBM key punch cards and

20
00:00:59.499 --> 00:01:05.240
then, well, there were a bunch of
weird sorta not too useful computers.

21
00:01:05.240 --> 00:01:08.200
There was the Tandy.

22
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:10.854
They had a computer,
and I had one of those.

23
00:01:10.854 --> 00:01:16.310
And I had a Cromemco, which actually
used an operating system pre-DOS.

24
00:01:16.310 --> 00:01:21.080
And it was kind of a personal computer,
but it had these eight inch floppies.

25
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:23.540
And it was a challenge.

26
00:01:23.540 --> 00:01:28.730
But it was better than using a typewriter,
I guess, to produce documents and stuff.

27
00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:34.320
So let's go to this first slide, because
we're gonna go through and look at dates.

28
00:01:34.320 --> 00:01:38.980
You can see up here on the first
bulleted item that they indicate that

29
00:01:38.980 --> 00:01:42.182
MS-DOS was issued in 1981 by Microsoft.

30
00:01:42.182 --> 00:01:45.339
And that was really
the first personal computer,

31
00:01:45.339 --> 00:01:50.310
true personal computer functional while
in office sort of Operating System.

32
00:01:50.310 --> 00:01:56.507
Although, they were competing at that time
with other competitors, but typically

33
00:01:56.507 --> 00:02:02.807
during this period of time you were using
dedicated word processors for office work.

34
00:02:02.807 --> 00:02:06.500
It might be a Wang, or
some other manufacturer.

35
00:02:06.500 --> 00:02:10.550
So, MS-DOS came out in
conjunction with the IBM PC.

36
00:02:10.550 --> 00:02:16.370
And IBM, fortunately I think, in looking
at it from a historical standpoint,

37
00:02:16.370 --> 00:02:19.230
they didn't make their machine,
their IBM PC,

38
00:02:19.230 --> 00:02:24.950
so that you couldn't copy it as
a result of copyright or patents.

39
00:02:24.950 --> 00:02:28.520
So a bunch of manufacturers
came out with IBM clones, so

40
00:02:28.520 --> 00:02:30.100
they were fairly commonplace.

41
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:34.470
And we were all using DOS,
just DOS for a number of years,

42
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:36.710
basically about ten or eleven years.

43
00:02:36.710 --> 00:02:39.940
And there was programs where
you could download them.

44
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:43.650
And eventually in, I think it was in 1992,

45
00:02:43.650 --> 00:02:47.860
Microsoft came out with a DOS GUI overlay.

46
00:02:47.860 --> 00:02:52.320
It laid on top of DOS and
you saw Windows 1,

47
00:02:52.320 --> 00:02:55.675
that never hit the market
on an earlier slide.

48
00:02:55.675 --> 00:02:59.740
And Windows 2 didn't hit the market
as a product that you could purchase.

49
00:02:59.740 --> 00:03:04.420
But ultimately,
Windows 3.1 was the first real

50
00:03:04.420 --> 00:03:08.210
Windows product that actually
worked in an office environment.

51
00:03:08.210 --> 00:03:11.070
And it was pretty good.

52
00:03:11.070 --> 00:03:16.830
It was widely adopted
from '92 to late '94.

53
00:03:16.830 --> 00:03:21.800
And in late 1994,
Microsoft came out with Windows 95.

54
00:03:21.800 --> 00:03:27.980
Everybody loved it and it was truly
a great operating system for its time.

55
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:32.920
And offices widely adopted it,
very quickly adopted it.

56
00:03:32.920 --> 00:03:37.720
They had Windows 95, they had a second
version of it that updated it,

57
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:39.658
made it even more powerful.

58
00:03:39.658 --> 00:03:44.510
And at or about a time of Windows
95 when it was first issued,

59
00:03:44.510 --> 00:03:49.018
Bill Gates who was the Chief Executive
Officer, the President of Microsoft,

60
00:03:49.018 --> 00:03:52.540
saw or
sensed this thing called the Internet.

61
00:03:53.750 --> 00:03:57.030
And prior to him making
this marvelous discovery,

62
00:03:57.030 --> 00:04:00.230
Microsoft had its own communication
protocol which meant it could

63
00:04:00.230 --> 00:04:02.905
easily communicate with
other Windows machines.

64
00:04:02.905 --> 00:04:05.340
At about the same time there,
were other companies out there,

65
00:04:05.340 --> 00:04:10.160
like Novell, that had their own
proprietary communication mechanism, and

66
00:04:10.160 --> 00:04:12.480
we call that a communication protocol.

67
00:04:12.480 --> 00:04:14.861
You'll hear protocol used a lot.

68
00:04:14.861 --> 00:04:18.257
But it could communicate
with other netwear devices.

69
00:04:18.257 --> 00:04:22.007
And Bill Gates look out at the Internet,

70
00:04:22.007 --> 00:04:27.636
which uses TCP/IP,
that's its communication protocol,

71
00:04:27.636 --> 00:04:32.490
and decided in a very smart

00:18:07.455 --> 00:18:09.365
>> Yes.
>> And its functionality, and

304
00:18:09.365 --> 00:18:11.855
by the way we had these square
looking things on the keyboard.

305
00:18:11.855 --> 00:18:16.415
>> And they changed the name with that
too, at first it was the metro interface.

306
00:18:16.415 --> 00:18:17.135
>> Yes.

307
00:18:17.135 --> 00:18:20.090
>> The tiles, they changed it a couple
of times so I'm not really sure.

308
00:18:20.090 --> 00:18:25.050
As of today, what they want you to call
that interface, the metro interface.

309
00:18:25.050 --> 00:18:29.120
But it's with the tiles and
we saw that because I think a lot

310
00:18:29.120 --> 00:18:32.300
of devices came out with
the touch screen capability.

311
00:18:32.300 --> 00:18:36.040
I could see where they're
going with the concept but

312
00:18:36.040 --> 00:18:40.210
people were used to and
familiar with their original Windows menu.

313
00:18:40.210 --> 00:18:41.412
And they wanted it back.

314
00:18:41.412 --> 00:18:41.944
>> Yeah.

315
00:18:41.944 --> 00:18:45.552
And I have a touch screen on my laptop and
I never touch it.

316
00:18:45.552 --> 00:18:48.360
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because I'm a keyboard sort of person

317
00:18:48.360 --> 00:18:49.990
and having all these stuff designed for

318
00:18:49.990 --> 00:18:53.220
touch just it wasn't me,
it just wasn't me.

319
00:18:53.220 --> 00:18:56.670
And so
we're kinda at the end of the history.

320
00:18:56.670 --> 00:18:58.160
We go to Windows 10.

321
00:18:58.160 --> 00:19:02.720
It's the most modern operating system.

322
00:19:02.720 --> 00:19:07.330
And Microsoft is doing a little bit of
a different thing with this desktop

323
00:19:07.330 --> 00:19:08.000
operating system.

324
00:19:08.000 --> 00:19:12.630
In that we're not looking for
11, or we're not looking for 12.

325
00:19:12.630 --> 00:19:15.230
What we're looking for is updates.

326
00:19:15.230 --> 00:19:17.760
And they have things like
the anniversary edition.

327
00:19:17.760 --> 00:19:20.820
And the new edition that's coming out,
I think in the Spring,

328
00:19:20.820 --> 00:19:22.930
is something called the creative edition.

329
00:19:22.930 --> 00:19:24.810
But it's still Windows 10.

330
00:19:24.810 --> 00:19:28.690
And the idea is that your
machine is automatically updated

331
00:19:28.690 --> 00:19:31.260
to these new renditions.

332
00:19:31.260 --> 00:19:34.670
And we were talking during the break
about how they expect to get paid

333
00:19:34.670 --> 00:19:35.600
relative to this.

334
00:19:35.600 --> 00:19:37.300
And it's a pretty good question.

335
00:19:37.300 --> 00:19:41.620
That's kind of an unknown but they're
getting paid when you buy a new machine.

336
00:19:41.620 --> 00:19:46.580
It's just my machine here, I theoretically
bought Windows when I first bought

337
00:19:46.580 --> 00:19:49.000
the machine, yet I didn't pay for 10.

338
00:19:49.000 --> 00:19:52.160
So kind of interesting, factually.

339
00:19:52.160 --> 00:19:55.210
Server side we're up to server 2016.

340
00:19:55.210 --> 00:19:55.710
>> 2016.
Yep.

341
00:19:58.150 --> 00:20:00.360
>> And that's the latest and greatest.

342
00:20:00.360 --> 00:20:06.530
So that kind of gives you an overview
of the history as it currently exists.

343
00:20:06.530 --> 00:20:09.820
>> I think that about wraps it up for
this episode.

344
00:20:09.820 --> 00:20:12.470
What we'll do though,
now that we've got the back story.

345
00:20:12.470 --> 00:20:14.290
We'll go ahead in the next episode and

346
00:20:14.290 --> 00:20:18.390
look at some of the basics and
get familiarized with the layout.

347
00:20:18.390 --> 00:20:19.540
How about that?

348
00:20:19.540 --> 00:20:21.535
>> And sorry for
taking you back so far in time.

349
00:20:21.535 --> 00:20:22.350
[LAUGH]
>> It's okay,

350
00:20:22.350 --> 00:20:23.930
we had a little bit of a time machine.

351
00:20:23.930 --> 00:20:25.440
Going on here today.

352
00:20:25.440 --> 00:20:28.240
But I think that does end
this particular episode.

353
00:20:28.240 --> 00:20:31.690
So go ahead and stay tuned, because
we've got more content coming your way.

354
00:20:31.690 --> 00:20:33.740
So for this episode,
we'll go ahead and sign off.

355
00:20:33.740 --> 00:20:36.220
As your host, Cherokee Boose.

356
00:20:36.220 --> 00:20:37.560
>> And I'm Steven Linthicum.

357
00:20:37.560 --> 00:20:40.703
>> See you next time here for
CyberPatriot.

358
00:20:40.703 --> 00:20:46.569
[MUSIC]

359
00:20:46.569 --> 00:20:49.763
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this this episode Professor Steve Linthicum and Cherokee explore a Windows operating system environment and explain components such as: The start menu, The directory structure, and file extensions.
episodes.title: Windows Basics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.505
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.505 --> 00:00:08.329
>> [CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.329 --> 00:00:10.912
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.330 --> 00:00:15.910
Welcome back, cyber patriots,
to another online training video.

5
00:00:15.910 --> 00:00:18.170
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.170 --> 00:00:22.240
In this particular episode,
we're gonna be looking at Windows basics.

7
00:00:22.240 --> 00:00:26.140
With us today to help us cover this topic,
is Professor Steve Linthicum.

8
00:00:26.140 --> 00:00:27.690
Thank you for joining us, Steve.

9
00:00:27.690 --> 00:00:28.500
>> Hi, everybody.

10
00:00:28.500 --> 00:00:31.760
We're gonna look at Windows basics and
it's really going to be basic.

11
00:00:31.760 --> 00:00:34.330
Because this is your starting point.

12
00:00:34.330 --> 00:00:36.380
You're gonna have to
build on Windows basics,

13
00:00:36.380 --> 00:00:39.830
based upon your own experience and
knowledge in the operating system.

14
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:42.340
And I know that we probably have
a wide variety of students.

15
00:00:42.340 --> 00:00:45.890
Some of you are quite familiar with
Windows, some of you may not be so

16
00:00:45.890 --> 00:00:46.990
familiar.

17
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:50.170
But this is your opportunity
to get really familiar.

18
00:00:50.170 --> 00:00:52.045
So we'll get you a starting point.

19
00:00:52.045 --> 00:00:55.110
You're gonna-
>> Take the initiative, we go from there.

20
00:00:55.110 --> 00:00:56.880
>> Exactly, exactly.

21
00:00:56.880 --> 00:00:58.490
So let's go to the first slide.

22
00:00:59.930 --> 00:01:00.830
>> All right.

23
00:01:00.830 --> 00:01:03.544
>> Okay, and that's the Windows basic,

24
00:01:03.544 --> 00:01:04.369
and-
>> The intro.

25
00:01:04.369 --> 00:01:06.140
>> So this is the second section.

26
00:01:06.140 --> 00:01:08.730
And I'm not gonna bring up my
screen relative to this, but

27
00:01:08.730 --> 00:01:13.370
I will in later slides, so that you
can actually see me doing some things.

28
00:01:13.370 --> 00:01:15.850
These are things that probably
are known to most of you.

29
00:01:15.850 --> 00:01:17.018
We have the recycle bin.

30
00:01:17.018 --> 00:01:22.330
So when you delete a file, or you delete
a folder, it actually gets transferred

31
00:01:22.330 --> 00:01:27.430
to the recycle bin and probably not
a good idea to immediately throw it away.

32
00:01:27.430 --> 00:01:30.720
Because you get a second chance
to throw that trash out, and

33
00:01:30.720 --> 00:01:34.580
it's akin to throwing it in
the trash truck when it drives by.

34
00:01:34.580 --> 00:01:39.140
It'll leaves your machine if you want to
do that, at this point, it's still there.

35
00:01:39.140 --> 00:01:43.835
You can bring it back to where it is,
by right-clicking on

36
00:01:43.835 --> 00:01:48.490
the trash bin and
restoring it to it's original location.

37
00:01:48.490 --> 00:01:51.180
Or, you can throw it
into the garbage truck.

38
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:56.390
And again, I don't encourage doing that,
unless you have security reasons,

39
00:01:56.390 --> 00:01:57.910
perhaps, for doing it.

40
00:01:57.910 --> 00:02:00.330
Or you just get tired of
seeing that trash can full.

41
00:02:00.330 --> 00:02:01.212
>> If you're really sure, yeah.

42
00:02:01.212 --> 00:02:05.630
>> Yeah, yeah, so I wouldn't
immediately be throwing stuff out.

43
00:02:05.630 --> 00:02:08.210
And then we have icons and shortcuts.

44
00:02:08.210 --> 00:02:10.220
These are on your desktop.

45
00:02:10.220 --> 00:02:13.870
They're different,
shortcuts have a little pointer on them,

46
00:02:13.870 --> 00:02:18.970
and they're actually a pointer to an
application somewhere on your hard drive.

47
00:02:18.970 --> 00:02:23.570
The ones that are without
the pointers are files

48
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:26.948
that are located actually on your desktop.

49
00:02:26.948 --> 00:02:31.485
And, I try to keep it clean,
because there are advantages to

50
00:02:31.485 --> 00:02:34.750
performance relative to not keeping
a lot of stuff on your desktop.

51
00:02:34.750 --> 00:02:37.105
Besides, it looks better,
it's like having a clean room.

52
00:02:37.105 --> 00:02:39.254
>> [LAUGH]
>> Versus a not so clean room.

53
00:02:39.254 --> 00:02:41.060
>> You dont want to see my PC, [LAUGH].

54
00:02:41.060 --> 00:02:42.297
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, yeah.

55
00:02:42.297 --> 00:02:46.630
You'll see mine, and I have some
up there that I frequently go to.

56
00:02:46.630 --> 00:02:48.790
That's a good reason for
having them up there.

57
00:02:48.790 --> 00:02:52.100
>> I normally dump things onto my
desktop if I'm working on them, and

58
00:02:52.100 --> 00:02:54.740
it's like a temporary kind of thing.

59
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:57.690
And I plan to plan to get rid of it,
or organize it, afterwards.

60
00:02:57.690 --> 00:03:00.235
But then you gotta stick with it and
actually do that, right?

61
00:03:00.235 --> 00:03:02.480
[LAUGH]
>> And I'm not that disciplined.

62
00:03:02.480 --> 00:03:07.480
So, if I put everything that I was working
on, on my desktop, it would be a mess.

63
00:03:07.480 --> 00:03:09.830
>> Gosh.
And now that I'm using a MacBook here,

64
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:12.050
you can have multiple desktops.

65
00:03:12.050 --> 00:03:14.170
And my gosh,
let's not even think about that, [LAUGH].

66
00:03:14.170 --> 00:03:16.190
>> Well, and a recent discovery for me,

67
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:18.366
is that you can actually
have that on Windows 10.

68
00:03:18.366 --> 00:03:20.170
>> Okay.
>> So, yeah, I don't use it, because-

69
00:03:20.170 --> 00:03:21.570
>> I never did either.

70
00:03:21.570 --> 00:03:23.330
>> All I need is two places to put trash,
right?

71
00:03:23.330 --> 00:03:26.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or trash up a desktop.

72
00:03:26.300 --> 00:03:28.780
So then we have the Start button.

73
00:03:28.780 --> 00:03:31.515
And we talked in the last
episode about Microsoft,

74
00:03:31.515 --> 00:03:34.860
in its infinite wisdom,
removing that Start button.

75
00:03:34.860 --> 00:03:36.700
And that turned out to be a bad idea,

76
00:03:36.700 --> 00:03:41.750
because people like me are used to getting
to programs by utilizing the start button.

77
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:44.518
And it has a left-click and a right-click.

78
00:03:44.518 --> 00:03:47.740
And that right-click provides
a lot of other capabilities,

79
00:03:47.740 --> 00:03:50.830
that would typically take you
multiple clicks to get to.

80
00:03:50.830 --> 00:03:53.666
iView in Windows, there's so
many ways to get to so many things,

81
00:03:53.666 --> 00:03:56.413
that the one that has the least
amount of clicks is my favorite.

82
00:03:56.413 --> 00:04:00.170
>> Right, and that's something you're
gonna learn from practicing it.

83
00:04:00.170 --> 00:04:02.810
There's really no better
way to actually learn that.

84
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:05.525
You're gonna learn tricks that
help you become more efficient and

85
00:04:05.525 --> 00:04:07.680
familiarized with that operating system.

86
00:04:07.680 --> 00:04:10.030
And you learn by doing it, so.

87
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:13.820
>> Yeah, a perfect example of the least
amount of clicks is why I have GodMode

88
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:15.080
on my machine.

89
00:04:15.080 --> 00:04:17.500
Because, typically the way
that you'll go through and

90
00:04:17.500 --> 00:04:20.510
you make configuration changes,
is that you gonna click the start button.

91
00:04:20.510 --> 00:04:24.642
You gonna either type in control panel, or
if you're in Windows 7, you can actually,

92
00:04:24.642 --> 00:04:28.700
there's a place where you can click and
get right into the control panel.

93
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:32.553
And we'll be talking more throughout-
>> I like their run line too.

94
00:04:32.553 --> 00:04:33.961
>> Yeah.
>> There are a lot of shortcuts you can

95
00:04:33.961 --> 00:04:35.950
use in the run line,
you guys can Google them.

96
00:04:35.950 --> 00:04:38.150
Keyboard shortcuts for
different operating systems,

97
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:40.920
if you haven't looked that up,
definitely do that, [LAUGH].

98
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:43.690
>> Yeah, it's like copy and paste.

99
00:04:43.690 --> 00:04:45.850
Copy to me is Ctrl+C.

100
00:04:45.850 --> 00:04:47.410
And paste is Ctrl+V.

101
00:04:47.410 --> 00:04:52.180
I seldom do it any other way,
because I am a keyboard sorta guy.

102
00:04:52.180 --> 00:04:58.010
And that's the old way that we used to
do it back in the earlier Windows days,

103
00:04:58.010 --> 00:05:01.855
and even programs outside of Windows,
like WordStar.

104
00:05:01.855 --> 00:05:05.540
There's a way that you would
bold using a key combination.

105
00:05:05.540 --> 00:05:06.890
The start of a bold and an end.

106
00:05:06.890 --> 00:05:11.150
So, there are a lot of
keyboard shortcuts that,

107
00:05:11.150 --> 00:05:14.610
as you get more experience,
you'll probably be using, okay?

108
00:05:14.610 --> 00:05:17.530
>> There was one more bullet here,
and it's definitely worth mentioning.

109
00:05:17.530 --> 00:05:19.340
It was the task bar on this slide.

110
00:05:19.340 --> 00:05:23.200
So, if we see at that horizontal
bar at the bottom of your screen,

111
00:05:23.200 --> 00:05:27.060
which can be moved to the right, top,
or left-hand side of the screen also.

112
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:31.821
But, that's somewhere where you can
actually pin applications for easy access,

113
00:05:31.821 --> 00:05:35.017
which I used all the time in
that kind of environment, so

114
00:05:35.017 --> 00:05:36.864
definitely take a look at that.

115
00:05:36.864 --> 00:05:41.586
>> Yeah, the ones that you commonly go to,
you'll pin to that task bar,

116
00:05:41.586 --> 00:05:43.630
it makes a lot of sense.

117
00:05:43.630 --> 00:05:46.490
So here we go on this next slide,
the first

118
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:49.790
thing that you're seeing up on top is when
you would actually hit the Start button.

119
00:05:49.790 --> 00:05:52.520
And what you would sort of see-
>> Over here.

120
00:05:52.520 --> 00:05:56.911
>> Over here on the left, those are
applications that you recently utilized.

121
00:05:56.911 --> 00:06:01.060
And then on the right, are common places
where you might be expected to go.

122
00:06:01.060 --> 00:06:04.140
For example, the Control Panel.

123
00:06:04.140 --> 00:06:09.540
Typically in a Windows 7 machine, it was
there, and in Windows 10, not so much.

124
00:06:09.540 --> 00:06:12.680
So you end up having to type
control panel to get to it,

125
00:06:12.680 --> 00:06:18.310
unless you reconfigure your machine
to have it over and available.

126
00:06:18.310 --> 00:06:22.656
And then that thing down below, we were
talking about, what was the metro or?

127
00:06:22.656 --> 00:06:24.890
>> The metro interface, yeah.

128
00:06:24.890 --> 00:06:25.960
>> Yeah, that's that thing.

129
00:06:25.960 --> 00:06:27.070
>> The metro tiles.

130
00:06:27.070 --> 00:06:27.630
>> Yeah.

131
00:06:27.630 --> 00:06:29.160
>> The live tiles.

132
00:06:29.160 --> 00:06:32.270
>> Yeah they weren't, yeah,
>> Right here, down at the bottom.

133
00:06:32.270 --> 00:06:33.890
And even here on the slide, it shows.

134
00:06:33.890 --> 00:06:37.448
So just remember that when Windows
8.1 brought back that Start button,

135
00:06:37.448 --> 00:06:40.678
people were kind of like revolting,
where did our Start button go?

136
00:06:40.678 --> 00:06:44.496
So that's why we see that quick release
of the newer version for Windows 8,

137
00:06:44.496 --> 00:06:46.590
the original version released.

138
00:06:46.590 --> 00:06:50.922
>> Right, and I remember, there were you
know there's always an application company

139
00:06:50.922 --> 00:06:53.008
out there that develops applications.

140
00:06:53.008 --> 00:06:56.959
And there was one developed by a number
of software houses that recreated that

141
00:06:56.959 --> 00:06:59.768
Start button for you,
when you were using Windows 8.

142
00:06:59.768 --> 00:07:00.492
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

143
00:07:00.492 --> 00:07:04.305
the first thing I did when I got on
a Windows 8 Machine, was to create that.

144
00:07:04.305 --> 00:07:05.130
>> And that's funny.

145
00:07:05.130 --> 00:07:08.380
Something you'll notice,
that whatever Microsoft does,

146
00:07:10.040 --> 00:07:15.410
there's usually a company that takes that
concept, that technology and expands

147
00:07:15.410 --> 00:07:19.270
upon it as a third party, and really
focuses and hones in one that one thing.

148
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:23.120
So, yes a lot is integrated into
these operating systems, but

149
00:07:23.120 --> 00:07:26.270
you're probably gonna find third
party tools that perform the same, or

150
00:07:26.270 --> 00:07:29.404
similar, functions out there as well
>> And maybe even do it better

151
00:07:29.404 --> 00:07:30.923
>> Yeah, I didn't wanna say that, but

152
00:07:30.923 --> 00:07:31.659
it's the truth.

153
00:07:31.659 --> 00:07:33.570
>> Well I'll say it, okay?

154
00:07:33.570 --> 00:07:37.480
So one of the things, the next slide
that comes up, if you can bring that up.

155
00:07:37.480 --> 00:07:41.640
This is the file and
folder segment in Windows Explorer.

156
00:07:41.640 --> 00:07:43.360
Now, let me explain something.

157
00:07:43.360 --> 00:07:48.090
Microsoft tends to overuse words,
and so with Windows Explorer,

158
00:07:48.090 --> 00:07:51.040
sometimes there's some
confusion with people.

159
00:07:51.040 --> 00:07:54.330
Sometimes I'll be talking about
using Windows Explorer, and

160
00:07:54.330 --> 00:07:58.250
I might be talking about using
Windows Internet Explorer.

161
00:07:58.250 --> 00:07:59.387
Two different things.

162
00:07:59.387 --> 00:08:01.720
>> Yeah, they sound the same,
but they're not.

163
00:08:01.720 --> 00:08:06.157
>> Windows Internet Explorer is
actually your road to the Internet, or

164
00:08:06.157 --> 00:08:07.849
your pathway to browser.

165
00:08:07.849 --> 00:08:12.090
>> Yeah, it is an outdated browser,
it's not supported by Microsoft anymore.

166
00:08:12.090 --> 00:08:16.370
They, well, they've pushed a new product
on us, and that would be Microsoft Edge.

167
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:20.150
So that's their replacement to
Internet Explorer, their browser.

168
00:08:20.150 --> 00:08:21.299
>> Exactly,
>> But

169
00:08:21.299 --> 00:08:23.041
I don't know anybody who's using Edge.

170
00:08:23.041 --> 00:08:29.956
>> [LAUGH] Okay, you're just,
[LAUGH] well, yeah.

171
00:08:29.956 --> 00:08:32.500
I'll keep my mouth closed on that one.

172
00:08:32.500 --> 00:08:35.055
>> Okay, so
let's switch over to my desktop so

173
00:08:35.055 --> 00:08:38.940
that you can get a live demonstration
of actually what's going on.

00:16:56.276 --> 00:17:02.680
this is a Windows 7 client machine, and
I probably, I really question running it.

328
00:17:02.680 --> 00:17:06.560
And particularly because we've got
something down here called FTP service.

329
00:17:06.560 --> 00:17:08.933
And FTP is a problem.

330
00:17:08.933 --> 00:17:10.423
>> Unsecure protocol [LAUGH].

331
00:17:10.423 --> 00:17:14.887
>> What happens is that stuff that
you send out FTP, to an FTP server,

332
00:17:14.887 --> 00:17:19.590
things like you're username and
password are not encrypted.

333
00:17:19.590 --> 00:17:21.370
And so,
you would probably go through here, and

334
00:17:21.370 --> 00:17:24.250
I'm gonna just simply kind of
get rid of some of this stuff.

335
00:17:24.250 --> 00:17:25.830
>> So, you're hardening your system.

336
00:17:25.830 --> 00:17:26.638
>> Exactly.

337
00:17:26.638 --> 00:17:33.070
And, sometimes they
mention things like media,

338
00:17:33.070 --> 00:17:35.580
this shouldn't be a media machine,
this is supposed to be a server.

339
00:17:35.580 --> 00:17:37.376
You're not supposed to be, so

340
00:17:37.376 --> 00:17:41.865
we have media features I don't know what
we have here but we got DVD Maker, and

341
00:17:41.865 --> 00:17:46.307
Media Center, and all these other stuff,
and so maybe we don't need that.

342
00:17:46.307 --> 00:17:50.589
>> And Microsoft kinda take the initiative
to do this on their server-side

343
00:17:50.589 --> 00:17:51.870
operating systems.

344
00:17:51.870 --> 00:17:54.770
And that's a feature
called features on demand.

345
00:17:54.770 --> 00:17:58.950
So they don't give you everything that's
available, you actually have to select

346
00:17:58.950 --> 00:18:02.130
what you do want instead of going through
and removing what you don't want.

347
00:18:02.130 --> 00:18:04.020
>> Right.
>> So just a little bit different concept.

348
00:18:04.020 --> 00:18:06.790
>> Right.
Some other things that as we scroll down

349
00:18:06.790 --> 00:18:08.130
here and take a look at.

350
00:18:08.130 --> 00:18:10.690
Well Telnet server.

351
00:18:10.690 --> 00:18:12.660
>> We talked about that
in a previous episode.

352
00:18:12.660 --> 00:18:15.310
We said, we don't like Telnet.

353
00:18:15.310 --> 00:18:18.592
>> But maybe we want a client,
because although we.

354
00:18:18.592 --> 00:18:21.100
I mean,
>> [LAUGH]

355
00:18:21.100 --> 00:18:22.860
>> I question that, obviously.

356
00:18:24.110 --> 00:18:27.660
Does this need to be a PC tablet?

357
00:18:27.660 --> 00:18:29.600
Probably a tablet PC, probably not.

358
00:18:29.600 --> 00:18:33.240
I'm not sure you're going to any points
for that, but we might get rid of that.

359
00:18:33.240 --> 00:18:34.960
Might get rid of that.

360
00:18:34.960 --> 00:18:37.060
A gadget platform.

361
00:18:39.480 --> 00:18:41.074
Probably don't need a gadget.

362
00:18:41.074 --> 00:18:45.524
>> I think Microsoft even
recommends not using those either,

363
00:18:45.524 --> 00:18:48.566
because they were a vector for malware.

364
00:18:48.566 --> 00:18:51.310
>> Right.
And as we go down through here,

365
00:18:51.310 --> 00:18:55.160
there are just a bunch of services that
you've really gotta take a hard look.

366
00:18:55.160 --> 00:18:58.610
RIP listener,
I know that we won't want that.

367
00:18:58.610 --> 00:19:02.180
And so, we go through and
we deselect those,

368
00:19:02.180 --> 00:19:04.920
we get rid of programs here we click okay.

369
00:19:04.920 --> 00:19:08.460
This takes several minutes, so
it's not even worth looking at.

370
00:19:08.460 --> 00:19:09.570
But it takes several minutes, and

371
00:19:09.570 --> 00:19:14.590
we're hardening the machine,
we're turning off unnecessary services.

372
00:19:14.590 --> 00:19:17.501
We're not only turning then off here,
we're removing them.

373
00:19:17.501 --> 00:19:20.710
And that's an important thing to do.

374
00:19:20.710 --> 00:19:22.050
>> Cool.
>> And we can go through, and

375
00:19:22.050 --> 00:19:25.690
one of the things that I recommend you
do on your own time, not on my time,

376
00:19:25.690 --> 00:19:32.020
is to go into the computer management,
getting through administrative tools.

377
00:19:32.020 --> 00:19:33.963
And go out in the internet and look and

378
00:19:33.963 --> 00:19:38.307
see what services are not critical that
you don't need to be running on a machine.

379
00:19:38.307 --> 00:19:43.640
And then go through and perhaps do like we
saw earlier, we disable those services.

380
00:19:43.640 --> 00:19:46.890
And, because, if you don't need them,
you don't need them.

381
00:19:46.890 --> 00:19:47.650
>> Right.

382
00:19:47.650 --> 00:19:51.060
So that's another avenue that you can
go through to harden your machine.

383
00:19:51.060 --> 00:19:53.730
>> Well thank you for showing us that
last tool, I do appreciate that.

384
00:19:53.730 --> 00:19:55.520
I know you guys appreciate that as well.

385
00:19:55.520 --> 00:19:59.560
I think that about wraps it up for
our performance monitoring tools.

386
00:19:59.560 --> 00:20:02.298
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this particular episode.

387
00:20:02.298 --> 00:20:06.522
And until next time, I'm gonna sign
off as your host, Cherokee Boose, and

388
00:20:06.522 --> 00:20:08.504
I'm Professor Steve Linthecome.

389
00:20:08.504 --> 00:20:12.353
>> See you next time here for
Cyber Patriot.

390
00:20:12.353 --> 00:20:17.938
[MUSIC]

391
00:20:17.938 --> 00:20:19.960
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

8

10

I hope you're going to enjoy this.

11
00:00:28.615 --> 00:00:33.170
We're switching operating systems, which
is going to make it kind of interesting.

12
00:00:33.170 --> 00:00:36.080
For those of you who are used
to solely a Windows environment,

13
00:00:36.080 --> 00:00:38.380
we're going to be looking at Ubuntu.

14
00:00:38.380 --> 00:00:41.030
And Ubuntu is a distribution of Linux.

15
00:00:41.030 --> 00:00:44.770
Meaning there are other distributions
that are similar in many ways,

16
00:00:44.770 --> 00:00:46.260
with some subtle differences.

17
00:00:47.640 --> 00:00:50.500
Very cool and so if I get this straight,

18
00:00:50.500 --> 00:00:54.630
it's almost as if Ubuntu, so
Ubuntu is a distribution of Linux.

19
00:00:54.630 --> 00:00:59.350
But we have other operating systems,
like Mac OS X and Linux and

20
00:00:59.350 --> 00:01:04.030
Ubuntu is also A derivative
of a Unix operating system.

21
00:01:04.030 --> 00:01:06.260
So it's almost like they're
related in this weird,

00:01:06.260 --> 00:01:08.806
twisted kind of family, [LAUGH]?

So what we're going to do is,

and they start out with the,

the basics of Linux including its nature.

Architecture, differences,

29
00:01:26.410 --> 00:01:28.171
Were going to do a Linux over view.

We're going to talk about Linux

the differences and

It's always good to compare the two

And we're also going to look at

line environment.

Ultimately, you'll get

37

Much more so
in Linux than you probably do in Windows.

38
00:01:54.330 --> 00:01:56.940
Simply because that's

39
00:01:56.940 --> 00:01:59.850
And believe it or not,
that's probably an obstacle for

40
00:01:59.850 --> 00:02:02.360
a lot of people adopting

41

There are good parts about it.

42

There are not so good parts about it,

What we're going to be looking

episodes.description: In this this episode Professor Steve Linthicum and Cherokee introduce you to the wonderful world of Linux.
episodes.title: What is Linux
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.140 --> 00:00:02.534
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host-
>> [INAUDIBLE]

2
00:00:02.534 --> 00:00:08.518
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.518 --> 00:00:12.221
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.221 --> 00:00:14.957
>> Welcome CyberPatriots to
another online training video.

5
00:00:14.957 --> 00:00:17.197
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.197 --> 00:00:21.400
In this episode, we're gonna be
looking at a very important question.

7
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:22.830
What is Linux?

8
00:00:22.830 --> 00:00:26.530
Kinda like that philosophical
question to be or not to be.

9
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:29.070
So to help us understand what Linux is,

10
00:00:29.070 --> 00:00:31.610
we have Professer Steve Linthicum
with us today.

11
00:00:31.610 --> 00:00:32.770
Thank you for joining us, Steve.

12
00:00:32.770 --> 00:00:34.230
>> Right, hi everybody.

13
00:00:34.230 --> 00:00:39.140
So, let's get started,
Linux is an open source operating system.

14
00:00:39.140 --> 00:00:41.220
It was modeled after Unix.

15
00:00:41.220 --> 00:00:44.440
Unix has been around forever,
and Unix, as a matter of fact,

16
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:48.810
was the first multi-user operating
system that came out there.

17
00:00:48.810 --> 00:00:51.450
And you're gonna see that when we
look at the architecture of it

18
00:00:51.450 --> 00:00:54.610
through its file structure, and
some limitations that are associated

19
00:00:54.610 --> 00:00:57.690
with it that doesn't really
exist in a Windows environment.

20
00:00:57.690 --> 00:01:02.285
So it can perform many of the same
functions as Windows and OSX.

21
00:01:03.320 --> 00:01:09.380
Incidentally OSX, the Apple operating
system, is really, it really is Linux with

22
00:01:09.380 --> 00:01:13.460
kind of a cover over it, a shield over it,
so you're not really seeing what's going

23
00:01:13.460 --> 00:01:16.060
on behind the scenes, so its files-
>> And they even use that term wall

24
00:01:16.060 --> 00:01:18.900
garden sometimes because it's
associated with that hardware,

25
00:01:18.900 --> 00:01:21.330
like you spoke on in a previous episode.

26
00:01:21.330 --> 00:01:26.550
>> Right, it's built in, it's
a collaboration, it's an open source tool.

27
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:31.630
Anyone can use Linux, they can modify it
and they can distribute the Linux kernel.

28
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:34.690
Anyone can develop software
that will run on it,

29
00:01:34.690 --> 00:01:38.930
many programmers collaborate to
develop and improve Linux, and

30
00:01:38.930 --> 00:01:44.140
many Linux operating systems have
add-on programs that are free.

31
00:01:44.140 --> 00:01:46.186
So free is a good thing obviously.

32
00:01:46.186 --> 00:01:47.266
Right?
>> [LAUGH] Yeah and

33
00:01:47.266 --> 00:01:49.287
actually if you look at my screen here,

34
00:01:49.287 --> 00:01:51.810
isn't this the cute little
icon that they have?

35
00:01:51.810 --> 00:01:53.640
That little penguin here?

36
00:01:53.640 --> 00:01:55.360
There we go just so
you're familiar with that, but

37
00:01:55.360 --> 00:01:58.410
different distributions may
have their own variation there.

38
00:01:58.410 --> 00:01:59.150
>> Yeah that's right.

39
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:04.300
So it refers to, as I mentioned,
a family of operating systems.

40
00:02:04.300 --> 00:02:08.382
And there are a whole bunch of varieties
out there, we call them distributions.

41
00:02:08.382 --> 00:02:11.043
There's daemon-
>> Destro sometimes

42
00:02:11.043 --> 00:02:11.653
people-
>> Yeah Destro-

43
00:02:11.653 --> 00:02:14.608
>> Slang [LAUGH]

44
00:02:14.608 --> 00:02:17.470
>> A little slag there, okay.

45
00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:23.175
So the Linux kernel is the core
component of the operating system.

46
00:02:23.175 --> 00:02:27.550
Windows Operating System also has
a kernel, but it's not open source,

47
00:02:27.550 --> 00:02:31.288
meaning we can't look at the source,
the actual program,

48
00:02:31.288 --> 00:02:36.760
the content, just source, I guess.

49
00:02:36.760 --> 00:02:40.610
>> The lower portion of that operating
system, the bones, if you wanna say.

50
00:02:40.610 --> 00:02:44.191
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, exactly, so.

51
00:02:45.580 --> 00:02:47.887
And we can have all kind
of good arguments back and

52
00:02:47.887 --> 00:02:51.844
forth about whether it's better to be open
source or close source like Windows is.

53
00:02:51.844 --> 00:02:56.557
And the argument that it's better to be
open source is that you've got a whole

54
00:02:56.557 --> 00:03:00.400
team, a whole world of programmers
looking into the kernel and

55
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:04.990
then adding programs associated with
it at no cost ultimately to the user.

56
00:03:06.170 --> 00:03:11.640
And with Windows we don't know
where the problems are potentially.

57
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:14.440
The security problems to be exact.

58
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:15.860
So you'll notice with Windows,

59
00:03:15.860 --> 00:03:21.420
periodically Microsoft is updating
by patching security holes.

60
00:03:21.420 --> 00:03:23.350
Same thing is happening
in a Linux environment,

61
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:27.110
but you've got a lot of cooks
in the kitchen with Linux.

62
00:03:27.110 --> 00:03:30.010
I guess that would be kind
of a way to describe it.

63
00:03:30.010 --> 00:03:33.710
And so the whole idea here is that

64
00:03:34.840 --> 00:03:40.290
there's a committee in effect, a world
wide committee that is improving Linux.

65
00:03:40.290 --> 00:03:43.860
And on Microsoft's side there's just
Microsoft's employees that are doing it.

66
00:03:43.860 --> 00:03:47.400
>> Yeah and you can have all sorts
of people contribute to the forums.

67
00:03:47.400 --> 00:03:50.665
A lot of support out there for
the open source community as well.

68
00:03:50.665 --> 00:03:53.922
>> Exactly,
now an operating system like Linux, and

69
00:03:53.922 --> 00:03:56.810
this is true with Windows,
or true with OSX.

70
00:03:56.810 --> 00:04:01.395
It manages memory, processes,
input, output devices.

71
00:04:01.395 --> 00:04:04.465
We talked about that in
earlier sessions where we were

72
00:04:04.465 --> 00:04:05.845
looking at an operating system.

73
00:04:05.845 --> 00:04:08.239
>> Yeah, and there's a nice little graphic
here we can look at on my screen too

74
00:04:08.239 --> 00:04:10.065
if you look at the slides here,
we'll see, there we go.

75
00:04:11.065 --> 00:04:15.880
>> Okay, and when a user does
something in the shell that's, and

76
00:04:15.880 --> 00:04:20.060
we refer to the shell as
basically a terminal.

77
00:04:20.060 --> 00:04:22.309
We're gonna talk more and more about that.

78
00:04:22.309 --> 00:04:25.806
Then the user is interfacing
with the kernel, and

79
00:04:25.806 --> 00:04:31.540
the kernel translates what the user is
asking it, the kernel to do and does it.

80
00:04:31.540 --> 00:04:35.750
So, and utilizes the CPU to
execute the instructions that

81
00:04:35.750 --> 00:04:36.870
you'll put in the terminal.

82
00:04:36.870 --> 00:04:39.070
And that's a new term.

83
00:04:39.070 --> 00:04:43.720
Look at it as the command shell in
Windows, that DOS sort of looking shell.

84
00:04:43.720 --> 00:04:46.729
And we're gonna take a look
at that in the next session.

85
00:04:48.170 --> 00:04:53.620
So we've got differences here, as I
mentioned earlier, we've got different

86
00:04:53.620 --> 00:04:59.411
flavors of Linux, Ubuntu, we've got
Fedora, we've got Red Hat, WN Linux Mint.

87
00:04:59.411 --> 00:05:01.640
There are a whole bunch of them out there.

88
00:05:01.640 --> 00:05:06.250
And frankly some users like some
distributions and some like others.

89
00:05:06.250 --> 00:05:08.770
It depends upon what you like.

90
00:05:08.770 --> 00:05:09.733
>> User preference, exactly.

91
00:05:09.733 --> 00:05:12.215
>> Yeah, yeah.
So it's kinda like going to the store and

92
00:05:12.215 --> 00:05:14.080
only having one type of bread.

93
00:05:14.080 --> 00:05:14.630
Well, guess what?

94
00:05:14.630 --> 00:05:18.820
You're gonna get tired of that one type
of bread and there isn't a choice.

95
00:05:18.820 --> 00:05:19.500
Here you've got a bunch of choices.

96
00:05:19.500 --> 00:05:22.971
>> A lot of options You can
even change the shells for

97
00:05:22.971 --> 00:05:25.775
the different distributions as well.

98
00:05:25.775 --> 00:05:27.875
So it's really flexible in that aspect.

99
00:05:27.875 --> 00:05:29.185
>> Yes, yes.

100
00:05:29.185 --> 00:05:33.325
And we call these, the term is we don't
call them distributions all the time.

101
00:05:33.325 --> 00:05:34.538
Sometimes we call them flavors.

102
00:05:34.538 --> 00:05:35.924
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

103
00:05:35.924 --> 00:05:42.320
>> Which is kind of an interesting term,
but they're different.

104
00:05:42.320 --> 00:05:43.330
The problem is, and

105
00:05:43.330 --> 00:05:47.790
maybe that's a handicap for
Linux with all of these different flavors,

106
00:05:47.790 --> 00:05:51.450
is the commands often time that we
use will have subtle differences.

107
00:05:51.450 --> 00:05:55.910
So you'll be on one machine typing in
a command expecting it to do something and

108
00:05:55.910 --> 00:05:58.030
you get an error in the command.

109
00:05:58.030 --> 00:06:00.740
>> Right, exactly like you were
talking about even with Mac OSX.

110
00:06:00.740 --> 00:06:02.970
Some of the Linux commands
will go ahead and

111
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:05.610
natively work in Max OSX,
some of them won't.

112
00:06:05.610 --> 00:06:07.810
So you'll just need to
kind of be aware of that.

113
00:06:07.810 --> 00:06:09.350
>> Yes.

114
00:06:09.350 --> 00:06:13.585
